a Radiation Application Research School, Nuclear Science and Technology Research Institute, P.O. Box 11365-3486, Tehran, Iran b Department of Chemistry, Razi University, P.O. Box 67149-67346, Kermanshah, Iran
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Aptamers Heavy metals monitoring Nanomaterials
A B S T R A C T
Recent developments in biotechnology offer the new methods for the sensitive detection of heavy metals based on the affinity and specificity of aptamers, as nucleic acid ligands selected from random sequence pools in vitro. Heavy metals have received considerable importance as the most toxic metallic pollutants which may cause serious environmental damages. They are classified as trace elements because of their presence in trace concentrations in various environmental matrices. Thus, the precise and sensitive methods to detect heavy metals are important to ensure human and environment safety. Aptamers as the biological probes, show high binding affinity which can often be directly translated into high detection sensitivity. On the other hand, high selectivity and stability make them possible to detect a wide range of targets, especially metallic ions. This review provides current progress of aptamers for environmental and biological monitoring of heavy metals using the nanomaterials mainly in two groups: (i) aptamer based biosensors (aptasensors) and (ii) aptamer based biosorbents (aptasorbents). The introduction of nanomaterials can efficiently increase the immobilization quantity of aptamers. Furthermore, they play an important role in the orientation and assembly density controlling of aptamers for the optimized recognition ability.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Heavy metals are widespread pollutants of great biological and environmental concern as they are non-degradable and thus persistent. They are released into the surface and ground water as a result of various activities such as industries, mining, and agriculture [1,2]. Heavy metals tend to easily accumulate in animals and human beings through the food chain system of the earth. The accumulation of these elements can cause severe damages to mucus tissues, intestinal tract, skeletal, central nervous system, liver, kidneys and reproductive systems [3,4]. They have potential towards production of the highly reactive chemical entities such as free radicals having the ability to cause lipid peroxidation, DNA damage, oxidation of sulfhydryl groups of proteins, depletion of antioxidants, and several other effects [5,6]. The long-term exposure to toxic heavy metals may also have carcinogenic effects in human and animals [7]. The level of these elements is an indicator of possible environmental pollution or pollution of the work place and life habits. So, the monitoring of toxic metal ions is an important issue in environmental protection, as well as disease prevention and treatment.
However, highly selective and sensitive detection of trace amounts
of heavy metals is really still a challenging research field. This is mainly due to the presence of high concentrations of interfering matrix components in most biological and environmental samples. Therefore, the capturing of target ions from a complex matrix is a key step in detection of heavy metals.
In recent years, the use of aptamers as the biological ligands has attracted significant interest. Aptamers, first introduced by three groups independently in 1990 are a type of artificial oligonucleotide probes generated by an in vitro technique termed SELEX (systematic evolution of ligands by exponential enrichment). They can bind to a broad range of targets, including small molecules [8,9], ions [10,11] proteins [12,13], cells [14,15], tissues and organisms [16,17]. These oligonucleotide probes offer several advantages over the traditional ligands, such as high binding affinity similar to that of antibodies that can be led to the high sensitivity, excellent selectivity, high stability and lack of immunogenicity and toxicity [18]. In addition, ease of synthesis and modification makes them ideal for recognition of heavy metal ions in biological and environmental samples.
Up to now, several DNA aptamers have been designed for the recognition and detection of heavy metal ions mainly Pb2+, Hg2+, Cd2+, Ag+ and As3+. These ions can specifically interact with bases of DNA to

form strong and stable complexes. The thymine (T) and guanine (G)rich of nonrepeating ssDNA sequences were identified for capturing of Cd2+ [19]. It has been reported that some metal ions such as K+, Na+, Ca2+ and Pb2+ could influence the conformational switch of a G-rich DNA from random coil to the G-quadruplex structure [20–22]. So, for detection of Pb2+, most works was based on the Pb2+-stabilized Gquadruplex [23,24]. It has been reported that, in the cases of Hg2+ and Ag+ ions, the T-T mismatches selectively captured Hg2+ to form T– Hg2+–T complex [25,26], and cytosine (C)-cytosine mismatches exclusively recognized Ag+ to form the C–Ag+–C complex [27,28]. The T– Hg2+–T bond results from the deprotonation and mercuration of the thymine N2, giving rise to N–Hg–N bond. This may distort the DNA structure, but strongly stabilizes the B-form DNA, with an extraordinary thermal stability [29]. The stability of the Hg–DNA complex was explained partly owing to the metallophilic attraction between mercury atoms in consecutive T–Hg2+–T base pairs [30]. In fact, the target metal converts T-T and C-C mismatches to stable base pairs. These are attractive due to reversible metal binding and simplicity. The ability of cations to bind nucleic acids and induce secondary structures can be attributed to such cation properties as ionic radius, coordination behavior, and hydration effects [31,32].
The formation of the T–Hg2+–T base pair structure in DNA duplexes was proved using the proton-1 (1H) and nitrogen-15 (15N) nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy [33,34]. The 1H NMR spectra presented four peaks between 10.4 and 11.1 ppm in the absence of Hg2+ due to the resonances of four imino protons of the T–T mispairs, in conjunction with those of the Watson-crick base pairing (at 12.5–13.5 µg L−1). However, with the addition of Hg2+, the imino proton resonances of the T–T mispairs almost disappeared, suggesting that the imino protons of the T–T mispairs in the Hg2+–free duplex were substituted with Hg2+ ions. For the characterization of DNA–metal base pair bonds, the 15N chemical shift perturbations upon the N–Hg2+–N bond formation were investigated. In addition, 15N–15N J-coupling (2JNN) across a metal center revealed the pairing mode and partners in T–Hg2+–T pairs. The 15N chemical shift changes for the T–Hg2+–T pairing and the related complexations exhibited lower-field shifts, which is sharp contrast to the higher-field shift of the 15N (guanosine) upon its innersphere coordination to Hg2+. It is interesting that 2JNN for 15N–Ru2+–15N as a reference compound is in the same order to those for the T–Hg2+–T pairs (2.4 Hz). Mercury199 NMR spectroscopy is also used to aptamer coordination modes. Dairaku et al. [30] have observed the 1-bond 199Hg–15N J-coupling (1J(199Hg,15N) = 1050 Hz) within the Hg2+-mediated thymine–thymine base pair. This strikingly large 1J(199Hg,15N) is the first one for canonical sp2-nitrogen atoms, which can be a sensitive structure-probe of N-mercurated compounds and a direct evidence for N-mercuration. The 1H NMR spectrum of C–Ag+–C complex related to imino proton region shows new peaks after titration with Ag+, where the intensities of these peaks increase with the concentration of Ag+, which confirms the duplex formation [35]. Therefore, the discovery of stable T–Hg2+–T and C–Ag+–C duplex formations enables the design of the novel methodologies based on the aptamers for determination of these heavy metals.
Recently, the coordination chemistry of metal ion-oligonucleotide bases has been highlighted in the development of biosensors and biosorbents. In fact, combined with some signal outputs, the T-rich, Grich or C-rich oligonucleotide ligands have been widely employed as recognition elements for Hg2+, Pb2+ or Ag+ detection. Due to the high specific interaction of these ions with bases, the designed detection systems can achieve excellent selectivity for target ion against other metal ions. In addition, the using of nanomaterials in these systems efficiently increases their performance. With the development of nanotechnology, nanomaterials are used as the platforms for immobi-
lization of aptamers [36]. They play an important role in the accumulation amount, orientation and assembly density controlling of aptamers for the optimized recognition ability. Nanomaterials may be also led to accelerate electron transfer in electrochemical biosensors [8,37,38]. A variety of nanostructures especially quantum dots (QDs) have been well-known as the fluorophores for fluorescent biosensing [39,40]. In addition, the fluorescent metal nanoclusters (NCs) are new class of materials, exhibiting a molecular-like spectroscopic behavior. Gold and silver nanoclusters have received considerable attention in the detection of a wide variety of analytes [41]. Several nanomaterials have revealed high quenching efficiencies toward a broad range of fluorophores, making them useful for fluorescence-based bioassays [42,43]. Over the last two decades, gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) have been used as the nanoassembly units for creating colorimetric biosensors, owing to their unique characteristics, including ease of synthesis, unique optical, thermal and electronic properties and excellent compatibility with biomolecules [44]. Especially, AuNPs intrinsic properties, namely surface plasmon resonance (SPR) and colloidal stability are contributing factors for a colorimetric generation [45]. In recent years, there has been a sharp increase in the number of groups working on the magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) and their applications. For the analytical applications, they have been used mainly for sample preparation techniques (magnetic solid phase extraction with different advanced functional groups [46,47]). Magnetic preconcentration of metallic ions was first employed by Towler et al. in 1996 [48], and he demonstrated the potential of magnetic separation for Ra, Pb and Po from seawater samples by using a magnetic sorbent (MnO on Fe3O4 NPs). The magnetic nanoparticles offer many advantages over the traditional non-magnetic sorbents. They can be easily isolated from sample solutions by an external magnetic field [49]. Thus, suspended MNPs tagged with the analytes can be removed from large volume samples in a short time. They alone or in combination with the other nanostructures are suitable surfaces for modification with capturing probes.
In this review, we provide a detailed evaluation of the aptamer based approaches developed so far for the analysis of the toxic heavy metal ions (i.e., Cd2+, Pb2+, Hg2+ and Ag+, As3+) by using various types of nanomaterials and in different configurations. The use of aptamer ligands in biosensors and biosorbents for determination of heavy metal ions is shown in Scheme 1. The described methods are attractive due to reversible metal binding and simplicity [10].

sections.heading: 2. Aptamer based strategies for determination of Pb2+
sections.text:
Lead is one of the most dangerous heavy metals which could cause serious impacts on the human organs and environment [50,51]. All forms of lead are toxic and adversely affect reproductive, nervous, immune, cardiovascular systems as well as developmental processes in children [52]. The maximum acceptable concentration of Pb2+ in blood is 10 μg dL−1, based on the Center of Disease Control and Prevention (CDCP) [53,54]. In view of the high toxicity of Pb2+ to public health, it is necessary to develop reliable, precise, and sensitive methods for the determination of trace amounts of this element in environmental and biological samples. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS), ICP optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), electrothermal atomic absorption spectrometry (ET-AAS), flame atomic absorption spectrometry (FAAS), ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectrometry and potentiometry are the most common analytical techniques for evaluation of Pb2+ [52,55]. However, these techniques require a separation/preconcentration step of target ion prior to the analysis. The increasing use of ion sensors in the fields of environmental and medicinal analysis is putting more and more pressure on analytical chemists to develop new sensors for the direct, accurate, fast and selective determination of heavy metals [56]. In recent years, colori-
metric, fluorescent and electrochemical aptasensors have been broadly utilized in the direct determination of Pb2+. The described aptasensors have the high potential for selective analysis of Pb2+ in samples containing other metal ions. Even, the cations known to stabilize Gquadruplexes such as Na+, K+ and Ca2+ showed signals that were only a little above background [22]. This is attributed to the highly specific binding capability between Pb2+ and the G-rich aptamer [57].

sections.heading: 2.1. Electrochemical aptasensors
sections.text:
With the development of the interactions between oligonucleotides and metal ions, aptamer molecules have been known as the powerful receptors in construction of electrochemical biosensors for Pb2+
detection. Li et al. [57] developed a sensitive and selective amperometric sensing platform for determination of Pb2+ in river water based on a Pb2+-induced G-rich DNA conformational switch from a randomcoil to G-quadruplex (G4) with crystal violet as the redox indicator. Crystal violet has the potential for hydrogen-bonding and cation-dipole interactions with negatively charged phosphate backbones and loops of G4. It efficiently intercalates into the formed G4, resulting in a readily measurable “turn–on” electrochemical signal. Because the amount of G4 is dependent on the concentration of Pb2+, the electrochemical response of crystal violet increases with increasing the logarithm of Pb2+ concentration over the range 0.001–1000 µmol L−1. The low detection limit for Pb2+ was estimated to be 0.4 nmol L−1 based on 3 s. Lin et al. [58] reported a label free DNA-based sensor for detection of Pb2+ in calf serum and lake water by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) with [Fe(CN)6]
4-/3- as redox probe. In the presence of Pb2+, charge-transfer resistance (RCT), which is the result of the resistance to charge transfer between the solution-based redox probe and the electrode surface, decreased. ΔRCT decreased linearly with the logarithm of Pb2+ concentration within a range from 0.01 to 10,000 nmol L−1, with a detection limit of 10 pmol L−1. Zang et al. [59] employed a “signal-on” photoelectrochemical sensing strategy for selective determination of Pb2+ in tap and lake water samples on the basis of the combination of Pb2+-induced conformational conversion, the amplified effect of reduced graphene oxide (RGO) and resonance energy transfer between CdS QDs and gold nanoparticles (AuNPs). Under optimized conditions, this “signal-on” photoelectrochemical biosensor exhibited a linear relationship between photocurrent varia-
tion and the logarithm of Pb2+ concentration in the range of 0.1– 50 nmol L−1 with a detection limit of 0.05 nmol L−1. A sensitive electrochemical aptasensor based on the carboxylic acid functionalized multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWNTs–COOH) and the direct electrodeposited AuNPs was developed for Pb2+ detection in water samples by Zhu et al. [60]. Methylene blue (MB) was selected as the G4-binding indicator and redox probe. The sensor could detect Pb2+ in a range from 0.01 to 50 pmol L−1 with a detection of 4.3 fmol L−1. Hai et al. [61] developed a “turn on”model of an electrochemiluminescence (ECL) based assay for Pb2+ in the complex biological samples such as blood and urine, with great application value. It was based on the formation of a G-quadruplex from an aptamer labeled with QDs and placed on an electrode modified with electrodeposited graphene and nano gold. ECL intensity was linearly related to the concentration of Pb2+ in the range of 10–1000 pmol L−1, with a 3.8 pmol L−1 detection limit. Deng et al. [62] proposed a novel analytical method for highly selective and sensitive detection of Pb2+ in soil samples. For sensing interface construction, L-cysteine (Cys) and AuNPs layers were electrodeposited on the electrode surface. The high-index-faceted AuNPs were prepared as nanocarriers to bind the polyamidoamine dendrimers (PAMAM) with the N–Au interaction. Then, the ECL luminophore of Ru-COOH was covalently bonded with the PAMAM to generate a selfenhanced ECL luminophore. Based on this analytical method, the ECL signal increased with Pb2+ concentration which presented a linear relationship in the range 0.1 pmol L−1 to 100 nmol L−1 with the detection limit of 0.04 pmol L−1. Recently, a label-free and highly sensitive electrochemical aptasensor for Pb2+ was reported by Gao et al. [63] using thionine as the signaling molecule and graphene as the signal-enhancing platform. The attenuation of electrochemical signal of thionine presented a good linear relationship with the logarithm of Pb2+ concentrations over the range from 0.16 nmol L−1 to 0.16 pmol L−1. The detection limit was estimated to be 32 fmol L−1. The developed electrochemical aptasensor was successfully applied for determination of Pb2+ in water samples. In the another study, Wang et al. [64] developed a label-free and portable aptasensor based on graphene field effect transistor (FET) for effective children blood lead detection. Based on the obtained results, detection limit was 37.5 ng L−1. In addition, Taghdisi et al. [65] fabricated an electrochemical aptasensor for the selective and ultrasensitive detection of Pb2+ in tap water and serum with detection limits of 326 and

sections.heading: 2.2. Fluorescent aptasensors
sections.text:
The last years have witnessed great progress in the development of fluorescent biosensors for the detection of Pb2+. Especially, recognition systems using aptamers have become interesting for the detection of this toxic element. Since these DNA-based detection systems are highly selective and sensitive for metal ions, a large variety of fluorescent biosensors have been designed for the sensing of Pb2+. Chen et al. [66] developed a facile and rapid strategy for the detection of Pb2+ ions with high selectivity and sensitivity using random double-strand DNAtemplated formation of CuNPs as fluorescence probes. It was found that Pb2+ can quench the fluorescence of dsDNA–CuNPs. Based on such a phenomenon discovered in this work, a label-free fluorescent aptasensor for Pb2+ monitoring in river water with a detection limit of 5 nmol L−1 was designed. Recently, GO has attracted much attention due to it can act as a “nanoquencher” for fluorophores by means of Förster resonance energy transfer (FRET) and as a “nanoscaffold” for ssDNA [67]. Single strand DNA can be spontaneously adsorbed onto the surface of GO by means of π-π stacking interactions between nucleotide bases and the GO sheet. For example, Li et al. [68] proposed a “turn-on” fluorescent aptasensor based on energy transfer from CdSe/ZnS QDs to GO for detection of Pb2+ in river water. The aptamer-conjugated QDs bound to the GO sheets to form a GO/ aptamer-QD ensemble quenched the fluorescence of QDs. After the Pb2+ ions were added, the fluorescence of the aptamer–QD was recovered. The linear response range of the aptasensor was determined to be 0.1–10 nmol L−1 with a limit of detection of 90 pmol L−1. Pang et al. [67] also designed a simple and sensitive sensing strategy for the determination of Pb2+ ions using GO as the fluorescence quencher. They adopted a FITC-labeled anticancer drug AGRO100 aptamer as the probe for recognition of Pb2+. Dye-labeled aptamer could be absorbed onto the GO sheet in the absence of Pb2+, and led to obvious fluorescence quenching as a result of FRET from FITC to GO. When Pb2+ was added, the conformation of the AGRO100 was switched to a special inter-molecular G-quadruplex/Pb2+ complex, which had a weak affinity with GO, and the fluorescence was restored. There was a good linear relationship between the fluorescence intensity of the dye and the concentration of Pb2+ ions in the range from 0.75 to 6.0 nmol L−1 with a detection limit of 0.40 nmol L−1. Another study showed the effect of GO on the graphene quantum dots (GQDs). In this investigation developed by Qian et al. [69], GQDs with high quantum yield, good biocompatibility were prepared and served as the fluorophore of Pb2+
probe. Fluorescence turn-off of GQDs was easily achieved through efficient photoinduced electron transfer between GQDs and GO, and subsequent fluorescence turn-on process was due to the formation of G-quadraplex aptamer–Pb2+ complex triggered by the addition of Pb2+. The established method for Pb2+ detection showed a broad linear range of 9.9–435.0 nmol L−1 with a detection limit of 0.6 nmol L−1. Wang and Si [70] developed a novel aptasensor based on multi-walled carbon nanotube (MWCNT) long-range energy transfer for sensitive, selective fluorescent detection of Pb2+ in homogeneous solution. The Cy5labeled aptamer was adsorbed on MWCNTs, leading to quenching of fluorescence of the dye. Desorption of the dye-labeled aptamer from MWCNTs, through the specific binding of the aptamer with its target, resulted in the restoration of the fluorescence signal of the Cy5. The response of the biosensor linearly increased in a range of 20– 150 nmol L−1 with the detection limit of 15 nmol L−1. In recent years, a lot of biosensors have been designed based on the super quenching capability of CNTs. For example, a simple and sensitive sensing method
employing ATTO 647N/aptamer-CNT ensemble for detection of Pb2+ was proposed by Taghdisi et al. [71]. In the absence of Pb2+, ATTO 647N-aptamer wrapped around single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNTs) and the fluorescence was efficiently quenched by SWCNTs. Addition of Pb2+ ions induced a conformational change and formation of a G-quadruplex aptamer/Pb2+ complex. So that ATTO 647N-aptamer left the side wall of SWCNT and fluorescence was turned on. The limit of detection was determined to be 0.42 nmol L−1. Developed sensor was used to measure Pb2+ concentration in tap water and rat serum.

sections.heading: 2.3. Colorimetric aptasensors
sections.text: Among the various optical methods, colorimetric aptasensors have attracted remarkable attention due to their features, including rapid response, simplicity and high sensitivity. Colorimetric assay is a common method for analytical applications, due to the target recognition event can be distinguished only by the naked eye [72]. In recent years, AuNPs have been broadly utilized in the construction of colorimetric aptasensors based on the unique phenomenon that welldispersed AuNPs solution is red in color, whereas aggregated AuNPs appear as a blue (or purple) color. Taghdisi et al. [44] developed a sensitive, selective and fast colorimetric aptasensor for Pb+2 based on polyethylenimine and AuNPs. In the absence of Pb+2, aptamer bound to polyethylenimine. So the well-dispersed AuNPs remained stable with a wine-red color. Upon the addition of Pb+2, a conformational change happened and a G-quadruplex aptamer/Pb+2 complex was formed, leading to the aggregation of AuNPs and a color change to blue. The fabricated aptasensor was successfully applied for detection Pb+2 in rat serum and tap water with a limit of detection as low as 702 pmol L−1.

sections.heading: 2.4. Aptamer functionalized nanosorbents
sections.text: In recent years, there has been an increasing growth in biomagnetic separation and preconcentration, primarily driven by the introduction of new biological ligands that overcome some of disadvantages of common ligands. Aptamers as the bioaffinity probes have revolutionized separation methodologies. In particular, the recent discovery of specific bindings of metal ions to oligonucleotides resulting in complex of metal ion-base pairs has led to the improvement of a number of methods for determination of heavy metals. For the first time, our group developed a selective and sensitive method for the determination of ultratrace contents of Pb2+ in biological samples, based on the Gquadruplex formed by the aptamer with hairpin structure and Pb2+ [73]. For this purpose, Pb2+ specific aptamer serving as affinity probe to capture and separate trace amounts of the analyte, was covalently linked to Fe3O4/GO surface by using a suitable cross-linking agent. Then, the G-quadruplex complex was formed by the opening of the “neck- ring” of the hairpin structure of aptamer in the presence of Pb2+. In this work, EDTA was used to elute the bounded analyte onto the biosorbent and then the concentration of Pb2+ was determined by ICP MS. Under optimum conditions, the calibration curve was linear over the range of 0.3–867.5 μg L−1 and an enrichment factor of 50 was obtained. The limit of detection (LOD) was 0.05 μg L− 1.

sections.heading: 3. Aptamer based strategies for determination of Hg2+
sections.text:
Mercury is a well-known highly toxic heavy metal that exists in metallic, inorganic and organic forms. As one of the most stable and wide-spread form of inorganic mercury, water-soluble Hg2+, released from both natural sources and industrial sources. The tendency of mercury to accumulate in the food chain has resulted in many outbreaks of its toxicity [74]. Mercury in both organic and inorganic forms is neurotoxic. The mercury-induced neurotoxicity has been reported to result in hearing loss, mental deterioration, speech difficulty, impaired vision, vestibular dysfunction and autism [75].
The mercury concentration in whole blood is usually lower than 10 μg L−1, but the value of 20 μg L−1 or below is considered normal. The blood mercury concentration can rise to 35 μg L−1 after long-term exposure to mercury vapor [76]. Considering low level of mercury in environmental and biological samples, the sensitive and selective detection of Hg2+ is urgently needed. Toward this goal, different analytical methods have been developed for mercury analysis, including neutron activation analysis (NAA), cold-vapor atomic fluorescence/ absorption spectrometry (CV-AFS/CV-AAS), ICP-MS, ICP-OES, UV– vis spectrometry, polarography, etc. [77,78]. As alternative methods, sensors have been demonstrated to be a quick and simple approach. In particular, aptamer-based biosensors with unique sensing characteristics provide opportunities for developing analytical new strategies with high sensitivity and selectivity. The bioassay systems based on the T-rich aptamers can achieve excellent selectivity for mercury against other metal ions, due to the high intrinsic specific T–Hg2+–T interaction [79]. Nowadays, many aptasensors combined with electrochemical transducers, fluorescence detection and colorimetric assays have been developed for Hg2+ determination.

sections.heading: 3.1. Electrochemical aptasensors
sections.text:
The use of aptamers in construction of electrochemical biosensors opens a new field for highly sensitive and selective determination of Hg2+. In addition, the application of nanomaterials to design electrochemical aptasensors for Hg2+ is nowadays one of the most active research fields. Lin et al. [58] reported an impedimetric aptasensor for determination of Hg2+ in calf serum and lake water based on the interaction of mercury with T-T mismatch to form T-Hg2+-T complex. The responses of ΔRCT against the logarithm of Hg
2+ concentration were linear from 0.1 to 1 × 104 nmol L−1 and a detection limit of 0.1 nmol L−1 was obtained. An et al. [77] described the fabrication and characterization of liquid-ion gated FET-type flexible graphene aptasensor with high sensitivity and selectivity for Hg2+. The graphene aptasensor showed excellent sensing performance, and Hg2+ ions with very low concentration of 10 pmol L−1 could be detected. Gao et al. [80] developed a highly sensitive and selective electrochemical aptasensor for determination of Hg2+ in real water samples, based on the formation of a ternary complex between the T-rich aptamer, the neutral red molecule and mercury ions without pre-modification of the probe aptamer. Since one aptamer strand could associate with eight probe molecules of natural red, the aptasensor could detect the Hg2+ as low as 1.5 pmol L−1, which suggested that the biosensor has great potential for practical environmental monitoring.

sections.heading: 3.2. Fluorescent aptasensors
sections.text:
As pointed previously, the CNTs can effectively quench fluorescence of the dye tethered to the DNA, which enables fluorescent detection of target. Based on this feature, several fluorescent aptasensors have been developed for detection of mercury. For example, Zhang et al. [81] reported a sensing approach for evaluation of Hg2+ using by FAMlabeled T-rich single stranded DNA and SWNTs. A practically usable range for quantitative determination covers a range from 0.05 to 8.0 µmol L−1 with a detection limit of 14.5 nmol L−1. Wang and Si [70] designed a MWCNT-based aptasensor for sensitive and selective detection of Hg2+ in homogeneous solution. In this research, the anti-Hg2+ aptamer was labeled with FAM. The proposed aptasensor had a linear range of 20–150 nmol L−1 with the detection limit of 15 nmol L−1. Li et al. [82] utilized water-soluble GO sheets as the quenchers, which were functionalized with single-stranded DNA aptamer. The presented GO-based aptasensor showed a limit of detection as low as 0.92 nmol L−1 for Hg2+. Pang et al. [83] developed a label-free and turn-on fluorescent aptasensor for Hg2+ via core-shell Ag@SiO2 NPs-based Metal-Enhanced Fluorescence (MEF). T-rich DNA aptamers were immobilized on the surface of Ag@SiO2 NPs and
thiazole orange was selected as fluorescent reporter. With introduction of Hg2+, the aptamer strand was bound Hg2+ to form T-Hg2+-T complex with a hairpin structure. Then, thiazole orange could insert into hairpin and the fluorescence quanta yield of thiazole orange increased under laser excitation and emitted a fluorescence emission. Furthermore, the fluorescence emission was amplified largely by the MEF effect of the Ag@SiO2 NPs. The proposed approach was tentatively applied to sensing Hg2+ in real samples such as tap water and lake water samples with a detection limit of 0.33 nmol L−1. Tan et al. [84] proposed a method for determination of Hg2+ in aqueous solution using the aptamer functionalized AuNPs based on the formation of T– Hg2+–T complex and the excellent quenching fluorescence property of AuNPs. Hg2+ was detected in a range of 0.02–1.0 mmol L−1 with a detection limit of 16 nmol L−1.

sections.heading: 3.3. Colorimetric aptasensors
sections.text:
In recent years, colorimetric sensors for determination of Hg2+
based on AuNPs have attracted much attention. Since thymine in DNA strands was demonstrated to bind Hg2+ specifically to form a stable THg-T complex, a variety of colorimetric biosensors based on DNA/ AuNPs have been developed for the selective detection of Hg2+. For example, Li et al. [85] reported a simple and sensitive aptamer-based colorimetric detection of Hg2+ in both tap and lake water samples using unmodified AuNPs as colorimetric probe. It was based on the fact that bare AuNPs interact differently with short single-strand DNA and double stranded DNA. When Hg2+ interacts with its aptamer, the aptamer is folded and then unmodified AuNPs could effectively differentiate the unfolded aptamer and the folded aptamer in the presence of a given high concentration of salt. This assay showed a linear response toward Hg2+ concentration through a five-decade range of 1 × 10−9 to 1 × 10−4 mol L−1 with a detection limit of 0.6 × 10−9 mol L−1. Liu et al. [86] also developed a colorimetric sensor for detecting Hg2+ in aqueous media, which was simply constructed by the self assembly of thymine acetamidoethanethiol (T-SH) on AuNPs. The TSH modified AuNPs induced to aggregate through the formation of a stable T-Hg-T complex in the presence of Hg2+, resulting in a color change from red to blue-grey. Using this colorimetric sensor, 0.5 μmol L−1 of Hg2+ could be easily discerned by the naked eye. Another study found that dispersed AuNPs have higher silver enhancement effect than aggregated AuNPs [87]. In fact, the enhancement effects of silver stain greatly depend on the number and the dispersion state of AuNPs. The mechanism involves monitoring the reduction of silver ions using labeled AuNPs as catalytic seeds. When AuNPs are dispersed, each AuNP is exposed to the silver enhancement solution, leading to a much greater surface area of AuNPs. A greater surface area catalyzed the reduction of more silver ions in per unit time, resulting in a darker color. Based on this phenomenon, an ultrasensitive method for the determination of Hg2+ ions was developed by Chen et al. [88]. The AuNPs were first coated with a single-stranded DNA aptamer rich in thymine. In the presence of Hg2+, the functionalized AuNPs aggregated due to the formation of T-Hg2+-T complexes resulting in a largely reduced surface area of the AuNPs when exposed to silver ions during staining. Therefore, fewer silver ions were reduced, and the average grey values, as measured by a scanner, were lower. The average grey values were linearly related to the logarithm of Hg2+ concentration from 1 to 500 nmol L−1. A similar research was done by Li et al. [89] using unmodified Au@Ag core-shell NPs based on a redox reaction between Ag-shell and Hg2+. The prepared Au@Ag core-shell NPs exhibited good monodispersity. In the presence of target, Hg2+ was reduced into Hg0 by Ag-shell, and deposited on the surface of Au core to form Au–Hg alloys and caused NPs aggregation. It led to the color changes of the solution from yellow to purplish red, and the SPR spectra of Au@Ag core-shell NPs red shift. Under the optimal conditions, the visual sensor could selectively detect Hg2+ as low as 0.4 l mol L−1 with the naked eye and 5.0 nmol L−1 by UV–vis spectra
analysis methods. The proposed visual sensor was successfully applied to detection of Hg2+ in tap and lake water.

sections.heading: 3.4. Aptamer functionalized nanosorbents
sections.text: Mercury and its compounds are included in all lists of priority pollutants, thus the monitoring or removal of Hg2+ is quite necessary. There are many coexisting interferences which seriously influence the detection or the removal efficiency of this toxic element, so the specific adsorption material for separation/preconcentration and removal of Hg2+ from the complex matrix is essential. Many materials have been reported for the adsorption of Hg2+ from aqueous media, such as solvent extraction [90], solid-phase extraction by molecular imprinted polymer [91], activated carbon [92] and other materials. To our knowledge, few studies have focused on the adsorption of Hg2+ using the specific interaction of mercury with thymine. Liu et al. [93] described a new kind of polymer sorbent based on the forming T– Hg2+–T complexes for the selective adsorption of mercury from aqueous solution. The mercury adsorption capacity was highly depended on the amount of thymine located on the sorbent surface. The thymine polymer sorbent was successfully applied for the selective adsorption of Hg2+ in real water samples. Recently, our group [94] reported a simple and sensitive method for analysis of trace Hg2+ in biological samples using the CV AAS, based on magnetic beads (MBs) separation/pre-concentration process and T-Hg2+-T coordination chemistry. The calibration curve was linear from 0.12 to 87.5 μg L−1. The limit of detection and enrichment factor obtained under the optimal conditions was 0.05 μg L−1 and 280, respectively.

sections.heading: 4. Aptasensors for Cd2+
sections.text:
Cadmium as one of the most extremely toxic metals tends to easily bio-accumulate in animals and human beings through the food chain system of the earth. The symptoms of acute cadmium poisoning include high blood pressure, kidney damage, anemia, hypertension, cancer, etc [95]. The acceptable blood Cd2+ concentration is approximately 5–10 μg dL−1 [96]. Such the strict guideline values promote researchers to develop more sensitive and reliable analytical methods for detecting and monitoring Cd in environmental and biological samples. Several of techniques such as ICP-OES, ICP-MS, ET-AAS, FAAS and potentiometry are popular methods for cadmium detection [95]. Kim et al. [97] have summarized many sensors for Cd detection. Most of these sensors usually required some organic ligands or complicated modifications. In addition, the receptors used in these sensors may not be biocompatible and selective. Therefore, it is still highly desirable to develop more sensitive and selective methods to detect trace cadmium in the real samples. Since the functional oligonucleotide ligands have been introduced as the target recognition elements in the sensing applications, some research has been done on the selection of aptamer for cadmium detection. Recently, Wu et al. [19] have in vitro selected the cadmium-binding DNA aptamer (named Cd-4 aptamer) using an affinity column based on the SELEX procedure. Interestingly, thymine and guanine were found as the two richest bases, which had almost occupied 90% of the total bases in a domain of 30-random sequences. This phenomenon may be attributed to the special interactions between Cd2+ and such two bases. Conversely, the adenine and cytosine lack enough sites for the formation of coordination bonds, so they may have weak affinity to Cd2+. They found Cd-4 aptamer have the highest affinity to Cd2+ with a Kd value of 34.5 nmol L−1, so this aptamer was further considered a recognition element for the simple detection of cadmium ions. According to the above results, they had proposed a novel colorimetric method for Cd2+
detection based on the aggregation of AuNPs by a special interaction between aptamer and poly(diallyldimethylammonium chloride) (PDDA). PDDA as a nucleic acid-binding cationic conjugated polymer is a water-soluble cationic polymer [98]. It acts as an agent for the
aggregation of AuNPs and also non-specific binding to the aptamer through electrostatic interaction. In the absence of Cd2+, the Cd-4 aptamer was free and hybridized with PDDA to form a “duplex” structure, thus the subsequent AuNPs could not aggregate owing to lack of PDDA. On adding Cd2+, the Cd-4 aptamer was exhausted firstly due to formation of Cd2+-aptamer complex, so that the subsequent PDDA could aggregate AuNPs which led to a remarkable change in color from wine red to blue. It was found that the change in color of the solution depends on PDDA concentration, which is in turn conditioned directly by the amount of cadmium. The proposed method was used for detection of Cd in aqueous solution with a detection limit of 4.6 nmol L−1. To test the selectivity of the proposed aptasensor, other competitive metal salts including Pb(NO3)2, Hg(NO3)2, AgNO3, KCl, CaCl2, ZnCl2, BaCl2, CrCl2, CoCl2, FeCl3, MgSO4, MnSO4, NiSO4, CuSO4 and FeSO4 were used. The results demonstrated that Hg
2+, Pb2+, Cu2+ and Zn2+ displayed some interference in Cd2+ detection.

sections.heading: 5. Aptasensors for Ag+
sections.text:
Silver compounds have low toxicity compared to those of most other heavy metals [99,100], as they are poorly absorbed by the human body when digested. In the large amounts, some silver compounds may be toxic, because silver ions have a high affinity for sulphur hydryl and amino groups, and therefore complexation with amino acids, nucleic acids and other compounds occurs in the body [101]. Furthermore, the silver ion is biologically active and readily interacts with receptors on mammalian and eukaryotic cell membranes [100]. The normal human serum content of Ag+ is lower than 2 µg L−1 [102]. Therefore, sensitive tracking Ag+ is highly desirable in environmental protection, as well as disease prevention and treatment. In recent years, various detection techniques adopting ICP-OES, ICP-MS, ET-AAS, FAAS and electrochemical methods were applied to selectively detect Ag+ [103,104]. Accordingly, much effort has been devoted toward the design of DNAbased biosensors for the detection of Ag+. For example, Lin et al. [58] reported an impedimetric aptasensor based on Ag+ interaction with CC mismatch to form C-Ag+-C complex. In order to further explore the potential application of the aptasensor in the practical samples, the assay was used to detect Ag+ in the 10-fold diluted newborn calf serum and lake water. The linear relationship between ΔRCT and the Ag + concentrations was ranged from 100 to 800 nmol L−1 with detection limit of 10 nmol L−1. Wang and Si [70] developed a fluorescent aptasensor using the 6-carboxy-X-rhodamine (ROX)-labeled anti-Ag+
aptamer and MWCNTs as the quencher. Importantly, the high specific surface area of MWCNTs allows the quenching of aptamer probes labeled with different fluorescent dyes. However, the binding between the aptamer and target can disturb the interaction between the DNA and MWCNTs, and release the dye-labeled aptamer from the MWCNTs' surface. The proposed aptasensing platform exhibited a limit of detection of 18 nmol L−1 for monitoring of Ag+. Zhan et al. [105] reported an off-on type of fluorescent assay based on the use of Ag+ specific aptamer, AuNPs and Rhodamine B (RhoB). The cytosinerich aptamer undergoes structural transformation with the introduction of Ag+. This results in a change in the aggregation status of the AuNPs and simultaneously affects the fluorescence intensity of RhoB that was added to the solution. The fluorescence intensity of RhoB is related to the concentration of Ag+ in the linear range of 2.73– 1500 µg L−1, and the detection limit is 2.73 µg L−1. The method was applied to the determination of Ag+ in spiked water samples.

sections.heading: 6. Aptamer based strategies for determination of As3+
sections.text:
Arsenic is a toxic carcinogen widely distributed in many parts of the world. Although arsenic exists in different chemical forms in nature, As3+ is considered to be the most toxic form of the element [106]. Humans are exposed to arsenic by direct and indirect ingestion, i.e., consuming crops grown from As-accumulated soils and contaminated
drinking water. Arsenic accumulates in tissues with high keratin content such as skin, hair, and nails [107,108] and is associated with a number of diseases such as skin damage, cancer or problems with circulatory systems [109]. This low permissible level has promoted researchers to develop more sensitive methods for arsenic detection. Currently, the popular methods for arsenic detection are chromatography, spectroscopic and electrochemistry methods [110]. These methods usually needed some reactions or modification, thus some of them may be susceptible to the surrounding conditions. Therefore, it is highly necessary to develop simple and stable methods to detect trace arsenic in the environment. In recent years, aptamers have been regarded as promising tools in environmental monitoring of heavy metals. Kim et al. [111] have in vitro selected the arsenic-binding DNA aptamer (named Ars-3 aptamer) using an affinity column based on the systematic evolution of ligands by SELEX process. Such a single-strand DNA aptamer contains 100 nucleotides and possesses the highest affinity to As3+ with a dissociation constant of 7.05 nmol L−1. Owing to the long chain of the Ars-3 aptamer, it is hard to modify them with fluorescent agents or redox labels for signal transduction. So, reports involving aptamer-based methods for arsenic detection have been rare. Wu et al. designed three colorimetric aptasensors for sensitive detection of As3+ in aqueous solution. The first design was based on the aggregation of AuNPs that was controlled by the interaction among PDDA, aptamer and As3+. In the presence of target, the aptamer was exhausted firstly due to the formation of an aptamer/As3+ complex, so that the following PDDA aggregates AuNPs, which leads to the remarkable change in color from wine red to blue. Through this approach, As3+ in aqueous solution was detected as low as 5.3 µg L−1 [112]. The selectivity of the biosensor for As3+ detection was also investigated. A variety of competitive metal ions, including As5+, Pb2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Ag+, Mg2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe2+, Fe3+ and Ca2+
were individually added to the sensing solution and the variations of absorbance values were calculated. The obtained results demonstrated that all the other metal ions displayed slight and negligible interferences on described systems for As3+ detection.
The second design was based on the aggregating AuNPs by the special interactions between arsenic-binding aptamer, target and hexadecyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) as a cationic surfactant. Aptamers and the CTAB could assemble to form a supramolecule, which prevented AuNPs from aggregating due to the exhaustion of cationic surfactant. With the addition of As3+, target specifically interacted with the Ars-3 aptamer to form the aptamer–As3+ complex, so that the following cationic surfactant could aggregate AuNPs and cause the remarkable change in color. The variations of absorbance intensity were exponentially related to the concentration of As3+ in the range from 1 to 1500 µg L−1, with a detection limit of 40 µg L−1 for the naked eye and 0.6 µg L−1 for colorimetric assay. Additionally, aptasensor exhibited high selectivity over other metal ions including As5+, Pb2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Ag+, Mg2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe2+ and Ca2+ with an excellent recovery for detection of As3+ in real water samples, suggesting that the proposed biosensor will play an important role in environmental detection [113]. In the third design, Wu et al. [114] described a colorimetric aptasensor based on the oxidization of 3,5,3′,5-tetramethylbenzidine (TMB) by the hemin–H2O2 system. Although hemin displays peroxidase liked catalytic activity, its ability is very limited due to the aggregation of them in aqueous solution to form catalytic inactive dimmers [115]. To improve its catalytic activity, hemin is fixed on the surface of nanosheets or enwrapped by guanineriched oligonucleotide to form the G-quadruplex structure, where each hemin molecule is in a state of active conformation [116–119]. In the proposed research, they found that arsenic-binding aptamers have a temporary inhibition on hemin catalytic activity [114] and the addition
of As3+ can recover its catalytic activity due to the formation of aptamer–As3+ complex. In fact, the introduction of As3+ can be led to the oxidation of TMB molecules and enhancement of absorbance. Through this approach, As3+ in aqueous solution was detected as low as 6 µg L−1 with high selectivity against other metal ions including As5+, Pb2+, Cd2+, Hg2+, Ag+, Mg2+, Zn2+, Mn2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Fe2+ and Ca2+. In an effort to provide an alternative removal method enhanced in removal efficiency with minimal interference, a new approach was proposed by Kim et al. [111] with Ars-3 aptamer serving as the removing agent of As3+. The specific binding of the Ars-3 aptamer to arsenic was confirmed using streptavidin agarose resin prepared with biotinylated Ars-3 aptamer and the same resin without the addition of the arsenic binding aptamer. The arsenic removal ability of the arsenicbinding aptamer Ars-3 was evaluated with groundwater samples collected from private wells of various areas in Vietnam.

sections.heading: 7. Conclusions
sections.text: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first systematic and comprehensive study that focuses on the new methodologies of sensing and separation of heavy metal ions based on the aptamers using nanomaterials. Since the invention of functional nucleic acids, they are incessantly exploited as the efficient sensing tools. Currently, the use of DNA or RNA aptamers in analytical chemistry is a very promising field of research because of their capabilities to bind specifically the targets with an affinity similar to that of antibodies. In this review, an overview of the considerable variety of aptamer-based separation/capture approaches that can be applied to the monitoring Pb2+, Hg+, Cd2+, Ag+, As3+ in environmental and biological samples has been presented. In recent years, considering to the economical, sensitive, selective and simple-to-construct, much attention has been devoted to the integration of oligunocleutide-based recognition elements with analytical techniques to develop the novel detection methods. In addition, with remarkable achievements in nanotechnology and nanoscience, electrochemical signal amplifiers, dyes, quenchers and sorbents based on nanomaterials have gained great potential for improvement of biosensors and separation/preconcentration approaches. So, we focused on the aptamer-based assays, in particular aptasensors in combination with nanomaterials. This is a very active area of research, where we will see the new and exciting developments for analysis of different targets.

metadata.abstractText: Recent developments in biotechnology offer the new methods for the sensitive detection of heavy metals based on the affinity and specificity of aptamers, as nucleic acid ligands selected from random sequence pools in vitro. Heavy metals have received considerable importance as the most toxic metallic pollutants which may cause serious environmental damages. They are classified as trace elements because of their presence in trace concentrations in various environmental matrices. Thus, the precise and sensitive methods to detect heavy metals are important to ensure human and environment safety. Aptamers as the biological probes, show high binding affinity which can often be directly translated into high detection sensitivity. On the other hand, high selectivity and stability make them possible to detect a wide range of targets, especially metallic ions. This review provides current progress of aptamers for environmental and biological monitoring of heavy metals using the nanomaterials mainly in two groups: (i) aptamer based biosensors (aptasensors) and (ii) aptamer based biosorbents (aptasorbents). The introduction of nanomaterials can efficiently increase the immobilization quantity of aptamers. Furthermore, they play an important role in the orientation and assembly density controlling of aptamers for the optimized recognition ability.
